if we use the hadoop admin page, when we search the log, we need too many operations. so we make this demand.

@nickpan47 Do you have any time table on releasing 0.12.0? We are trying to use Samza on Aliyun, which is a Chinese large cloud provider and their message service recently started to support standard kafka 0.10 protocol as an internal release. If we can directly upgrade to Samza 0.12.0 before their formal release, which I suppose will happen in two or three months, it will save our team a lot of work and will be worth waiting.

Hi, Aries,

That's awesome news! The expected timeline for Samza 0.12 should be within
a month. I think it will well fit in your timeline!

Cheers!

-Yi

This is really cool @prateekm ! I have some thoughts on it :)
If this is an unwindowed join, and we are setting the TTL for tuples in the joinState, shouldn't we  have a default TTL value so we don't get OOM exception too often? wdyt? Also the  "purging procedure" of removing tuples from the join state should also include removing old tuples from each relation internal state, so they don't grow unboundedly either. Maybe this is on the patch and I missed it ;)

@vjagadish1989: I'm working through the pull request locally as discussed. One observation: we're losing type information in WindowOperatorImpl and when I add the missing type information (e.g. to spec.getWindow()) the types don't match up (e.g. there is an assumption that K = WK that is not explicitly worked out in the type system). I would suggest taking a look.
My bad. I just read the JIRA :)
Is there any code change associated with your JIRA other than the dependency change, @fredji97  ?

@renato2099 Thanks for the feedback!

For some context, this is an early version of the Join API and implementation. We'll add support for more join types and a persistent state store soon.

1. A default TTL: We decided against adding one in this implementation since it's hard for the framework to make a reasonable guess about the value - it would depend on the memory allocated to the container and the incoming message throughput and size. The plan is to add support for a persistent state store soon, so in the mean time it's probably better to let the users set a value based on their expected usage.

2. Expiring from relation internal state: In this implementation there's no separate join state, only the internal state for each relation (contained in its "PartialJoinFunction"). Join results are emitted as matches are found, and entries are purged from the relation's internal state when they're older than the TTL. There's another possible version where a match causes the entries corresponding to the emitted results to be removed immediately, but we decided to implement this more general version instead.

Does this make sense?

Yes, there is another PR#72 for the code change. 
Thanks,
Fred

    On Thursday, March 2, 2017 11:17 AM, Navina Ramesh <notifications@github.com> wrote:
 

 Is there any code change associated with your JIRA other than the dependency change, @fredji97 ?—
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

Thanks for the reply @prateekm ! :)
For (1) fair enough, it's better to make the user define a proper TTL.
For (2) I see what you mean. I thought the two in-memory hashmaps were used to keep both streams states, and that the join result was also kept in another hashmap which could be consumed from the next operator or handed to the user who would see it as an evolving data set.
But yeah makes sense to pass it and let the next operator figure out what it needs (i.e. stateless vs state-full). Cool! thanks for the explanation @prateekm !

@navina github isn't letting me address your last comment inline so quoting here:

> Quick question orthogonal to what we are discussing here: If the separation of logical and physical identifier for stream is aiding the HDFS use-case, how are they doing it now? Right now, does HDFS not support stream level properties?

A combination of luck and simple use cases :-)
The luck part is that we happen to parse task.inputs such that we get the system name first and then assume everything after the "." is the stream name. But this wouldn't work if there were commas or spaces in the stream name.
The other part is that I haven't seen an HDFS case that sets any stream specific properties. Thus they avoid the config pattern 
systems.file-system.streams.file://my.dir/my.file.avro.samza.msg.serde
which is harder to parse. And it will get even worse when we start supporting any properties s.t. they don't all have a samza.* suffix.

@jmakes Yeah. Something is wrong with github. 

>  But this wouldn't work if there were commas or spaces in the stream name.

Commas are treated as list separators in some of configs. i would guess its the same way it is treated in most "properties" based config definitions. I don't think spaces make sense in any config definition :)

>Thus they avoid the config pattern systems.file-system.streams.file://my.dir/my.file.avro.samza.msg.serde

Yeah. It is one thing for us to say that they can avoid. A whole other thing to say we are blocking it actively for their sake. Right now, they don't actually call out that they cannot configure stream-scope properties (may be they should :D)  We should be facing the same problem with databus and the only reason why it works is because of how we parse it (anything after a .) . 

While rolling out this new way of configuration, is it going to be backward compatible with the current config definition? That is why I asked the question.

@navina 

> >But this wouldn't work if there were commas or spaces in the stream name.

> Commas are treated as list separators in some of configs. i would guess its the same way it is treated in most "properties" based config definitions. I don't think spaces make sense in any config definition :)

Lets try another example then. When the user wants to define some property called "my.prop" on a stream called "my.stream.name"

How should samza parse the config:
systems.mySystem.streams.my.stream.name.my.prop=value

Where does the stream name end and the property name begin?

By introducing rules for logical identifiers (system and streamId) we can ensure that the identifier is always parseable. 

Would you not agree we're at risk with our current wild-west anything-goes approach?

And yes. This patch is fully backward compatible. The new config style takes precedence, but the old configs are still read. As @nickpan47 suggested though. Maybe a rewriter is cleaner.

> Would you not agree we're at risk with our current wild-west anything-goes approach?

Yes, I agree to that. I was again concerned only about compatibility. It seems like we all want to have more stricter rules on our config hierarchy and nomenclature. May be, this is a good time to discuss it, even if we don't fully implement it. 

> And yes. This patch is fully backward compatible. The new config style takes precedence, but the old configs are still read. As @nickpan47 suggested though. Maybe a rewriter is cleaner.
I think you and Yi have already clarified this. Thanks!

Yes, `oldestOffsets` is defined as immutable Map var, so any modification operations return new map without modification of current. In all other places `oldestOffsets` is reassigned, but here is not.

I personally prefer immutable val's, but it seems a big change and imply refactoring of at least this method.

@cpettitt-linkedin I tried to make the changes you recommended in terms of keeping either synchronous start & stop or asynchronous start & stop.  Here are the roadblocks I have hit :)

* On a fully synchronous API: ZkJobCoordinator is fully asynchronous ( See PR #70 & PR #50 ) - meaning, streamProcessor.start() simply starts the Zk JobCoordinator - which will participate in the leader election and then, WAIT on notification for the jobmodel to be available. Waiting for the notification is not time-bound and can take very long time , if the processors group is constantly changing. Hence, the creating a blocking call with a timeout may not be a good idea for StreamProcessor user. 
(Additionally, ZkJobCoordinator implementation doesn't bind to the contract defined in JobCoordinator interface :( I have created a JIRA to fix this [SAMZA-1147](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SAMZA-1147) )

* On the other hand, if we make start/stop asynchronous, we should provide callbacks for the user. I took a stab at adding callbacks for the processor lifecycle - onStart (invoked just before container starts the runloop), onStop (invoked when container has fully stopped) and onError (invoked when container fails/throws an exception). This looks good, however, it does not capture any error that can happen in the Job Coordinator. I am little confused about whether it sufficiently provides the user control over the behavior of the processor. 

* Another point of difference (between pre-Zk and post-Zk world), StreamProcessor managed both jobcoordinator and container. But now, we have refactored it in a way that StreamProcessor manages JobCoordinator, which in turn, controls the container life-cycle. I feel like the latter is not the best approach as it seems to pollute the JobCoordinator interface with StreamProcessor requirements. 

These are my 2 cents. We can sync-up in-person if it is hard to evaluate the options in the PR.
Probably easiest to discuss. My calendar is pretty open today and tomorrow if you'd like to set something up.
Move this to a private repo. We may consider move this PR back to open source if there are more clear needs from open source community.
@navina @jmakes : please take a look. Thanks!

@nickpan47 :

>> I do prefer to make the whole queue of callbacks, the context to schedule and cancel callbacks in a single class (maybe TriggerCallbackScheduler??). 

Prefer not to do this, Wouldn't this will move complexity (and simply a bunch of code) from `WindowOperatorImpl` to a different`TriggerCallbackScheduler` class? The context to schedule and cancel callbacks must be created *per* trigger key instance.

>>The functions that refer to a lot of WindowOperatorImpl internals can stay in the inner classes that mainly implementing callback functions to be invoked by the scheduler.

I extracted out inner classes for greater readability into their separate files. 

To move forward on this, I see two approaches here.

Approach 1:
- I can rename the current `TriggerContext` class to a `TriggerScheduler` and create a new  `TriggerScheduler` instance (with the same `pendingQueue`) for every `TriggerKey`.

Approach 2:
- Have a single `TriggerScheduler` instance and have each of the individual `TriggerImpl` classes pass in their `triggerKey` when they call `schedule(durationMs, runnable, triggerKey)`.

Update: I went ahead, and implemented `Approach 2`.

closing this one as we are introducing a new approach to for universal resource localization.
https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/90

Thanks for your quick response.  Our use case is that we have many stores / changelog topics and two typical configurations: simple test deployments with a single Kafka node (and therefore want a single changelog replica) and production (and more complex test) )deployments where we currently configure three replicas.  The system default is two.  Therefore we currently need to explicitly list each of the changelog topic stores in our configuration files or they inadvertently default to two.  Easier for us would be to configure a single changelog replica default and only if necessary configure a store specific one.  In other words our desired number of replicas does not currently vary by store, but, instead by deployment topology.

I put some of this information in the JIRA, but, failed to copy it into the pull request.

@vjagadish1989 Should I rebase it against master, since it has conflict now?

Couple of notes on recent changes that I pushed. 
1. We are missing "state" definitions for each of the components interacting in StreamProcessor - namely, JobCoordinator and SamzaContainer. This makes it difficult for us to define the state of the StreamProcessor. For now, it merely keeps track of whether JobCoordinator was started or not (JobCoordinator does not provide a way to check status). Making these changes is much larger scope and I hope to tackle it in SAMZA-1147 and SAMZA-1150. 
2. Similarly, there is no clear error handling semantics for JobCoordinator. It was straightforward with StandaloneJobCoordinator because JobCoordinator was simply a pass-through. So, we were interested only in failures in SamzaContainer. With the introduction of other JobCoordinator implementations, we need to handle the interaction between JobCoordinator and Container to propagate errors up the stack. With this patch, we propagate only container errors using the callback. With SAMZA-1150, errors from jobcoordinator should also propagate to the user.

I have kept the above changes in separate JIRAs as it has much larger scope. 

Other changes:
* Added unit tests for SamzaContainerController 
* Added unit tests for StreamProcessor 
* Changed stop() api in StreamProcessor to syncStop()

Fyi, there are going to be more changes based on SEP-2's requirements/design. We should align the sync/async behavior of our APIs based on that.
